Mason v. Coleman, 480 Mass. 531 (2018).support_reasoning: The user has not actually specified any substantive proposition; the field after 'PROPOSITION CLAIMED:' is blank. The opinion clearly addresses Massachusetts Rule 36 speedy trial calculations, excluded periods, and acquiescence, but whether that supports the (unstated) proposition cannot be evaluated.
Mason v. Coleman, 480 Mass. 531 (2018).relevant_excerpt: "We also hold that time can be excluded under rule 36 based on a defendant's acquiescence only where the defendant has agreed to or failed to object to a continuance or other delay, and that the scheduling of an event alone does not constitute delay. Thus, a defendant need not object every time an event is scheduled in order to preserve his or her rights under rule 36. We further hold that, where the defendant has acquiesced, a delay can be excluded under rule 36 even where it does not affect the presumptive trial date."

Adams v. Harris, 462 Mass. 163 (2012).support_reasoning: The proposition field is blank (“CITATION OF APPLICABLE LAW:” with no stated rule or principle), so there is no concrete legal proposition to compare against the opinion. While the case clearly concerns mandatory 60‑day deadlines and dismissal absent extraordinary circumstances in G.L. c. 123A proceedings, I cannot determine whether it supports an unspecified proposition. Without a defined proposition, I must treat the support question as not established.
Adams v. Harris, 462 Mass. 163 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The sixty-day deadline required by G. L. c. 123A, § 13 (a), is ‘mandatory to protect a defendant’s liberty interest, and any delay by the Commonwealth that results in a confinement exceeding sixty days is a violation of the statute.’ … Such delays may be excused only where there exist ‘extraordinary circumstances that would justify a very brief delay.’ … Absent ‘extraordinary circumstances,’ any violation of the sixty-day statutory deadline, however brief, requires dismissal.”

Smith v. Jones, 376 Mass. 65 (1978).support_reasoning: The user did not provide any actual legal proposition or stated principle—only the heading 'PROPOSITION CLAIMED: CITATION OF APPLICABLE LAW:' with no content following it. Without a specific proposition to compare against the case’s holding, it is impossible to determine whether Smith v. Jones (actually the Baker sanding-rights case) supports it. The opinion mainly addresses whether a profit à prendre for sanding a cranberry bog is extinguished by commercial infeasibility and related abandonment/obsolescence issues.
Smith v. Jones, 376 Mass. 65 (1978).relevant_excerpt: "On the issue of obsolescence, we expressly rejected the view that 'a profit à prendre created for a special purpose is extinguished when it would be commercially impractical or economically wasteful to attempt to revive the activity which the profit was created to serve.' Konner, supra at 469. We stated that '[a]n interest in the nature of an easement is not terminated when the purpose for which it is created is neither totally nor permanently impossible of enjoyment.'"

Black v. White, 359 Mass. 48 (1971).relevant_excerpt: “In the case at bar, we adopt the rule that the commencement of the disability itself, and not the time when the proof of that disability was submitted, operated to effectuate the waiver provision. … We are of opinion that the defendant’s obligation to waive the premiums commenced when the insured became totally disabled.”

While the opinion discusses strict compliance with rules for petitions to establish a report and the need for a verified allegation that the report conforms to the truth, I cannot say it supports an unspecified proposition.
Green v. Brown, 325 Mass. 25 (1951).relevant_excerpt: “A petition to establish a report, like a petition to establish exceptions, is strictissimi juris… By Rule II… a party seeking allowance of a report is required to file ‘his petition verified by affidavit of the party or his attorney setting forth in full his claim for such report and all facts material thereto.’… The petition in this case contains no allegation that the draft report… sought to be established conforms to the truth….”

Johnson v. Johnson, 299 Mass. 455 (1937).support_reasoning: The user did not actually supply any substantive proposition; the field after 'PROPOSITION CLAIMED:' is just 'CITATION OF APPLICABLE LAW:' with no legal principle stated. Without a concrete proposition to compare against the opinion’s holding (which concerns the effect of refusing a plaintiff’s request for a ruling that the evidence warrants a finding in his favor, and when such refusal is harmless), it is impossible to determine whether the case supports it.
Johnson v. Johnson, 299 Mass. 455 (1937).relevant_excerpt: “If such a requested ruling has been refused, and nothing more appears than that a general finding for the defendant has followed, that general finding will be deemed the result of a ruling, implicit in the refusal of the ruling requested, that the evidence did not warrant a finding for the plaintiff. If the evidence did warrant such a finding, the refusal of the requested ruling is error, because the plaintiff has been deprived of the right to have the evidence considered upon the material issues of fact.”

Roberts v. Smith, 276 Mass. 60 (1920).case_name: LaFrance Industries v. City of Boston
Roberts v. Smith, 276 Mass. 60 (1920).support_reasoning: The proposition field is blank, so there is no specific legal proposition to compare against the opinion. Without knowing what legal principle the case is being cited to support, I cannot determine whether the opinion supports it. The case primarily concerns the requirements for valid service of a notice to admit facts under St. 1926, c. 381, § 1, and the inadmissibility of deemed admissions when service requirements are not met.
Roberts v. Smith, 276 Mass. 60 (1920).relevant_excerpt: “St. 1926, c. 381, § 1, requires that the notice to admit facts must be served by copy on the other party or his attorney. Service by copy, as the statute enacts, is not complied with by sending notice through mail, as was done by the plaintiff. Service by copy means service by an officer authorized to serve civil processes. … As the plaintiff did not serve the notice as provided by the statute, it was not entitled to the benefit given it because of the defendant’s failure to answer within the ten days.”

Davis v. Wilson, 250 Mass. 40 (1918).case_name: Lonergan v. American Railway Express Co.
Davis v. Wilson, 250 Mass. 40 (1918).support_reasoning: The proposition field is effectively blank (“CITATION OF APPLICABLE LAW:”) and does not state any specific legal principle to evaluate against the case. Without a defined proposition, it is impossible to determine whether Davis v. Wilson supports it. The opinion does address issues such as skidding not being negligence per se and the rule that new legal issues cannot as of right be raised first on a motion for new trial, but no concrete claimed proposition has been provided to compare against.
Davis v. Wilson, 250 Mass. 40 (1918).relevant_excerpt: "It is the long established and frequently applied rule of practice in this Commonwealth that a party cannot as matter of right raise a question of law on a motion to set aside the verdict and grant a new trial, which might have been raised before verdict. While a judge may in his discretion permit such a question to be presented on a motion for a new trial, he cannot be required to consider it."
